title: SYNTHIA: Novel Concept Design with Affordance Composition
author: Xiaomeng Jin (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Hyeonjeong Ha (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Jeonghwan Kim (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Jiateng Liu (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Zhenhailong Wang (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Khanh Duy Nguyen (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Ansel Blume (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Nanyun Peng (University of California Los Angeles), Kai-wei Chang (University of California Los Angeles), Heng Ji (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign)
relevance_why: The framework's emphasis on generating functionally coherent designs aligns well with potential applications in audio and music generation, particularly in merging concepts from different audio domains.
background: The paper presents a framework for generating novel designs by combining different functional affordances into a single coherent concept, utilizing text-to-image models.
contribution: SYNTHIA introduces an affordance composition framework to solve the challenge of generating functionally coherent concepts, achieving significant improvements in novelty and coherence metrics.
technical_comparison: Previous methods primarily focused on aesthetic variations without ensuring functional integration of multiple components. This work improves by incorporating a hierarchical concept ontology and a curriculum learning approach that enhances the compositional reasoning of text-to-image models.
key_innovation: The method uniquely integrates hierarchical affordance sampling with curriculum learning to guide the generation of visually distinctive and functionally coherent designs.
real_world_impact: The framework could be applied to various domains to inspire creative design processes, such as in product design and architecture, enhancing the role of AI in creative industries.
limitations: The authors acknowledge that their concept ontology may not cover all possible categories, which could limit the applicability of the proposed approach.

new_terms.affordance: **Affordance** refers to the potential uses or functionalities that an object offers to users, integral for guiding design processes.
new_terms.hierarchical concept ontology: **Hierarchical concept ontology** is a structured representation of concepts organized into levels that capture relationships among visual elements and their functionalities.
